p.b: Re. Hierarchy Semanitcs - notes from Jozsef Bedocs

ul.li: I contend that system, subsystem, assy, component (or whatever other names one substitutes here) are not the names of levels of hierarchies for design elements; but the names of types of associations between design elements and their organizations.

Also, naming levels of hierarchies for design elements is futile, because hierarchy is true only for a named design element. If one steps back to look at the collection of design elements and their inter-relationships; one would not call what they saw hierarchy.

Please entertain the use of the word Design. While we are not trying to make a language, if we want a systems data exchange to be used, it has to be clear and concise or it won't be used. Apparently the words being batted around are insufficiently clear.

But what is clear in engineering is the word Design. It doesn't matter if you talk to a software, electrical, chemical, biological or nuclear engineer (or any other type of engineer), design is design. Designs are things that we may or may not build. Metrics, such as mass, power, dimensions, reliability, etc are associated with elements of design.

p.b: Re. Hierarchy Semanitcs - notes from David Price

ul.li: My understanding has been basically that "STEP Product"

ol.li: - has implicit subtype "design of thing" which
- has subtype "STEP Part" which
- has implicit subtypes "detailed part" and "assembly"

ul.li: So, Joe did hit the core of the issue by bringing "design" into the discussion
Tom was also right "STEP Product" is now much broader in scope than "design of thing".

p.b: Re. System and Product - notes from David Oliver

ul.li: In Asheville we decided as a team to place System at the level of Product, essentially equivalent to Product

ol.li: - The Product Identification arm then provides a name, ID, description and categorization for System.
- The Product Version arm provides a version with ID and description for System Version.
- The Product Version Relationship arm provides a sequencing of later to earlier versions or a hierarchy of versions
- The Product View Definition arm provides ID, name, and additional description for System view definition, and a context with application domain, life cycle stage and description.
- The Product View Definition Relationship arm provides relationships among Product View Definitions

ul.li: From the point of view of applications, making System equivalent to Product means that we need to have designs and real manufactured things at the same high level in the model. We also need to have interfaces among Systems, among Designs, and among real manufactured things. It must be possible to keep these interfaces consistent, and to attach interface requirements to them.

p.b: Re. Part the Design of real manufactured things - notes from David Oliver

ul.li: The Part and Version Identification Arm defines Part as design and makes Part and Part Version subclasses of Product and Product Version.
Part View Definition arm makes Part View Definition a subclass of Product View Definition

p.b: Re. Part - notes from Erik Herzog

ul.li: I would appreciate if you could provide more information on the use of part objects. In document based systems engineering the set of physical objects identified are, e.g., identified in an SSDD (System Subsystem Design Description). The granularity of these descriptions are of course system dependent, but typically at a very high level of abstraction and not necessarily intended for realisation (i.e., they are conceptual). Requirement traceability is normally provided in the document format as well.

My question here is whether using part is the right thing to do. The alternative would be to represent the physical components using a special subtype of product, thus indicating that the physical component "thingy" is a conceptual element, i.e., a requirement in another format and not intended to be seen as a realisation element.

This question may appear trivial, but has some value for the creation of CM baselines. A SSDD type document would normally be part of the functional baseline and frozen early in the process. If physical objects are treated as part then they would naturally evolve over the processes and it would be difficult to capture whether new versions of the objects are due to changes in the requirements or the natural design evolution.

p.b: Re. Part - notes from Tom Thurman

ul.li: Erik: Excellent question! I would encourage you and others interested to consider developing a use case to formally drive out details.
However, here are some thoughts:

ol.li: The AP210 project has taken the approach that the STEP - product objects (i.e., product entity in ISO 10303-41) should have as few top level subtypes as possible. The reason is that the product object is the focus of product identification and commerce. The descriptions of a product you describe most likely are properties of the STEP - product_view_definition object or may be properties of the relationship between two such STEP - product_view_definition objects.

It is quite dangerous for me to make such a statement without seeing some actual data because but I trust you are talking about things like - the speed shall be at least 60 mph at zero deg Centrigade - for this version of the product.

The granularity and level of abstraction of physical reality the properties represent is exactly decided by the agreed scope of the AP and is realized in the different types of Product_view_definitions an AP creates (and the relationships between those views.

ul.li: From my interpretation of the STEP part object, and how we use it in AP210, it is only intended to be for products which contain atoms when delivered.
Other subtypes of product for instance software is intended to be information and not atoms (when software is combined with specific media e.g., a CD that combination is considered to be a part).
Somewhere I have an AP210 presentation Lothar and I did at the recent PDES Inc. offsite. It shows some of the AP210 usages of product subtypes and product_view_definition subtypes.

It is limiting to have a product subtype, product_version subtype, and product_view_definition subtype tree, as those are currently consstrained to force exactly one type of product_view_definition for the product subtype, and we may decide that that is not a good thing. I am not sure how this came to be, but it seems to be relatively recent in STEP (i.e, only appeared with stepmod development as far as I know.)

I personally don't know at what stage the part identifier (as opposed to the STEP product_concept, product_model object identifiers) is known. This may play an overriding role in deciding this issue for AP233. It was deemed a non-issue in AP210 during reviews of the activity model, so that model assumes all the product identifiers are known, as well as the id owning organization.

p.b: Re. Real manufactured things - notes from David Oliver

ul.li: In the Product as Individual arm, Product as Realized represents versions of real manufactured things. Product as Individual View represents the details of particular versions of Product as Realized and it appears to be an appropriate representation for the details about versions of real things.

Summary: Under the decision to make System equivalent to Product, we can use Part for design and Product_as_individual_view for real manufactured things. It is critical for us to know if this solution works. We still need to decide whether to use Interface arm, Product_interface_arm or a third solution to represent interfaces.

p.b: Re. Assembly - notes from Sean Baker

ul.li: The problem with the concept of assembly is that some user's "part" is another user's assembly

From the STEP viewpoint, saying something is an assembly is equivalent to saying you have the breakdown into smaller physical components. "assembly" is not a classification of the thing in itself, but an observation on whether your organization thinks about it in terms of components.

In a PDM context, an assembly is something that is in itself configuration controlled (in a configuration context), and is made from configuration controlled parts. Here, an assembly is a convenient holder for "a collection of parts". It would not affect the end product if a different collection of assemblies were used, as long as the same collection of parts in the same position is the result. The old 'Product Manager' explicitly supported the restructuring of the design assembly breakdown into a manufacturing assembly breakdown. There are also often differences between the assembly structure used in manufacture and the assemblies provided as spares.

Which all goes top reinforce that "assembly" is as much a description of the user organization as the product. Since STEP does not transfer business processes, it is probably best to treat "assembly" as a placeholder for a family of concepts that need further specification.

p.b: Re. Assembly - notes from Gerry Radack

ul.li: If you are saying that it does not make sense to say that an Assembly is a kind of Product or Part I agree. Assembly should be treated as a relationship which is part of a structure. We should be able to say "A is assembled from B, C and D within structure X" but not "A is an assembly". Different structures are needed to account for different activities or purposes, e.g., manufacture, maintenance, and disposal.

p.b: Re. Assembly - notes from Lothar Klein

ul.li: In STEP an assembly is not a Product but a view to a version of a part.
A Part_version can have many views some of them can be assemblies others not. E.g. for the same part_version we may have

ol.li: an assembly_view "as designed"
an assembly_view "as manufactured" which could be quite different
a non-assembly view for the customers/users of the product

ul.li: All this is covered by AP214. In addition AP214 has

ol.li: a mating_definition view to be able to say how things are connected with each other in very detail

a collection_definition view. This is needed if you have e.g. a part which is a pair of shoes, consisting of the left one and the right one (each one is its own part). A pair of shoes is not an assembly but a collection.

ul.li: AP210 adds further detailed views such as usage and design views.

p.b: Re. Breakdown - notes from the Editor

ul.li: Considerable debate surrounds the breakdown modules of stepmod
AP233 has no desire to take an EXPRESS modeling preference position
Self imposed constraints on AP233

ol.li: provide AP233 problem needs detail
harmonize with AP210/AP214/AP239/APxxx
listen/act to consensus of experts

p.b: Re. Breakdown - notes from David Oliver

ul.li: In Asheville we decided as a team to place System at the level of Product, essentially equivalent to Product. Additionally it was decided that we will not in this inital draft attempt to us

ol.li: Functional Breakdown arm
Physical Breakdown arm
Product Breakdown arm
System Breakdown arm

ul.li: This raises three questions

ol.li: If these four arms are not used, will AP233 mappings to applications and AP239 mappings to applications be in harmony?
How does AP239 map these four arms to applications?
What are the definitions for System Breakdown, Functional Breakdown, and Physical Breakdown? The existing documentation does not tell us.

ul.li: NOTE: There appears to be dis-harmony on the notions surrounding the concept of breakdown wthin the STEP community

p.b: Re. Breakdown - notes from Lothar Klein

ul.li: I [Lothar Klein] propose to arrange an WG3/WG12 session on breakdown at the SC4 Valencia meeting. It is important that in SC4 we come to a commonly accepted models which can serve all APs and requirements.
Note that all the modules are on TS level only! So we should be free to do incompatible changes where needed when it supports interpretability between different APs.

In STEP a part_version is a kind of product(_version) which someone can build or buy. Main characteristics of a part is that it has no variants (it is fully specified) and that you may have one or several Product_individuals (those which might have a serial number and which are the focus of PLCS).

For variant products and the early design phases AP214 introduced a "conceptional product structure" (see UOF S7). At about the same time the concept of "product breakdown" was introduced in the NATO/CALS Product Data Model (NPDM/NCDM) which can serve similar purposes.

With the modularized development of AP236 and AP239 we got now the breakdown module and specialisations (zonal, functional, ...) intended to cover the "conceptional product structure" of AP214 and further needs.

To the question whether or not AP233 needs breakdown I would strongly suggest to say YES. AP233 works in the early design phase were we have only vague structures which are clearly not assemblies or well defined "collections" as indicated above. So breakdown is the right thing to go for.
BIG! But I have to say that I have *big* doubts about the details in the breakdown modules.

ol.li: For me a breakdown is only a *view* to a version of a product, but not a product by itself !!!!!
PLCS developers told me that a breakdown must be its own product - but they failed to convince me so far.
I propose to remove all specialisations of Product and Product_version for breakdown.
The primary entity is Breakdown_element_definition (and subtypes).
People should use for its "defined_version" and "of_product just the supertypes product/product_version if they don't know if it will be part a document, an individual or whatever.
Further detailed changes on the breakdown module are needed in my opinion (e.g. on Breakdown_of), but this will be too much for this email.

ul.li: AP233 - BOTTOM LINE Caution is advised!!!!!!!!!!

For some future version of AP210 I could see the need to have combined functional and zonal breakdowns of a PCA/PCB to separate digital and analog areas; or high voltage and low voltage. But these would be additional views to a part_version, which also has PCA/PCB views.

When an airplane with a given serial number is split into regions for business and economy class this is a zonal_breakdown *view* of an individual product at a particular period of time (it may be different for the next flight).

ol.li: We should not introduce an artificial Zonal_breakdown at the product level for this.

ul.li: To support a highly variant product such as a car we have to combine the breakdown structure with specifications and expressions to be able to say which combinations of components are valid and which are not.

ol.li: In AP214 all the is done on the view level (product_definitions). AP236/239 misses to introduce a product for such a Variant_part.

p.b: Re. Breakdown - notes from David Price

ul.li: The PLCS team believes the core requirement for the separation of Product Design from System Breakdown came from the AP233 team. Therefore, they are a bit confused by the idea of AP233 not using it.

ol.li: Reason: Neither the AP233 problem nor the AP239 solution was understood in sufficient depth. Opinion were given; but not AP233 commitments could possibly have been made. An understanding of all relevant aspect of the AP233 problem was not fully understood.

ul.li: The concept behind the use of the various concepts is based on the following scenario.
During early concept design, System breakdowns are created by SEs (and yes, here I mean the AP239 concept of breakdown)
Progressively, the system elements that are related to the system breakdown are related to functions (functional breakdown) or potential products (product breakdown)
At some point, real products need to be designed and the STEP Product assembly (i.e. Parts) concept is used.
AP239 also covers the Product as Individual (i.e. thing in the real world) but I'm not sure that really affect this discussion on the use of breakdown by AP233. It may though.
It is the understanding of the PLCS team that both AP233 and PLCS will need both the breakdown and assembly concepts.

It seems to me that what they've described holds together even if the definitions in the actual STEPMod modules aren't sufficient to explain all this. Also, in Asheville we discussed mapping "The SE Term System" to "The STEP Product Entity". The argument was that "SEs mean almost anything when the say System" and so STEP Product was the closest concept. However:

ol.li: after more thought I'm not sure that matters.
We are not defining the terminology SEs use, we are defining an information model for exchange.
If, for the purpose of exchange, we need to make distinctions between System Breakdown, System Element, Product Design, and Product As Individual then AP233 should include those concepts.

ul.li: If we can fix any errors or extend in these PLCS modules working with that team so they work for AP233 we get a long way towards supporting AP Interoperability. Which is a big requirement for some given AP233 took the modular approach.

p.b: Re. Breakdown - notes from Erik Herzog

ul.li: Yes, sometime during the last millennium we made the distinction between the product design and system design structures, and I would be very much worried if this distinction was not maintained.

However, I have been away from STEP too long to immediately grasp the breakdown concept and to assess whether our original intentions is supported (those intentions may of course not be valid any more). Are there any examples available?
WHAT IS - " the distinction between the product design and system design structures" ???????

ol.li: The product to one is the system to another
I see no distinction - this makes me nervous

p.b: Re. Interfaces - notes from David Oliver

ul.li: The Interface Arm is subclassed to Product, Product Version, and with a general capability for assignment. This appears to be a good solution for interfaces but it may not work. The population of Interface Arm is a critical issue for us to learn if it works.

An alternative arm for interface called Product Interface arm has been placed in the Structure Draft 4. It is modeled on the AP210 Physical Unit Interconnect Definition arm. That AP210 arm is subclassed to Part view definition. As Tom Thurman told us at Asheville, this means the AP210 module applies only to design, to Part. The Product Interface arm is subclassed to Product view definition so it is a possible solution. We critically need to know if those most expert in EXPRESS believe that the Product Interface arm will work. We critically need to see if the Product interface arm can be populated with a simple example. We need to choose the better of Interface arm and Product Interface arm or find an even better solution.

p.b: Re. Interfaces - instance diagrams from Phil Spiby EUROSTEP.

ext_description.p: The instance diagrams below represent an interface between a 13A UK power outlet
and a computer
made using a "kettle-style" power lead
Clearly, such an interface may be represented at different levels of detail.
The completed interface beween to power-outlet and the computer (see above) is represented with varying degrees of complexity ways below:
NOTE: Example classifications shown as blue text.
1: As an interface between a power-outlet and a computer:
ext_description.Caption: Figure 1: power-outlet / computer interface
ext_description.p: 2: As interfaces between a power-outlet, a power-lead, and a computer:
ext_description.Caption: Figure 2: power-outlet / power-lead / computer interfaces
ext_description.p: 3: As interfaces between a power-outlet, a 13A plug, a cable, a 13A "kettle-style" female connector, and a computer:
ext_description.Caption: Figure 3: power-outlet / plug / cable / connector / computer interfaces
ext_description.p: 4: As a (hierarchically structured) hybrid of interfaces between a power-outlet, a power-lead, and a computer; and a more detailed set of interfaces between a power-outlet, a 13A plug, a cable, a 13A "kettle-style" female connector, and a computer:
ext_description.Caption: Figure 4: hybrid: simple and detailed interfaces

p.b: Re. Interface - notes from Lothar Klein

ul.li: Yes, this is a great work. But unfortunately if you look in more detail it proves that the interface module is not working

ol.li: The pictures indicate that this example deals with product_individuals (those with a serial number)

Instead it may be better to describe the whole thing on a "typical" design level. This is having an assembly or collection of an occurrence of an outlet, an occurrence of a computer and an occurrence of a cable.

But instead the example data population works only on the definition level (part_view_definition) There are occurrences of the connectors, but no occurrences of the computer, cable and outlet. In other word, these examples say that every computer is connect with this kind of cable to this kind of outlet which is definitely not true since here in Germany we connect the computer with a different kind of cable to a different type of outlet. This problem can't be solved on the definition level!

ul.li: Try to add two extension cords "EXT-A" and "EXT-B" of the same type (part.name="EXT") to this example and you will see that you can't describe the overall connections without having part_occurrences of outlet(wall), cable, extension, computer and these occurrences have to build a higher level of assembly (or collection).
I agree to the requirement to be able to describe such connections without going down to the detailed terminal level.

p.b: Re. Analytical model - from the editor

ul.li: "_lite" modules simply strip away all but the obvious (to the editor)
as the above takes form so to will the analytical model capability

p.b: Re. Product_rule - from the editor

ul.li: "_lite" modules simply strip away all but the obvious (to the editor)
as the above takes form so to will the product rule capability
product rules are tightly coupled to requirments. May want eventually to move this module to the requiirements module set.
product_rule is tightly linked to AP210. A looser connect is needed to enable the reuse by AP233

p.b: Re. System physical architecture modelling alternatives within AP-233 - from Erik Herzog, Syntell AB

ul.li: References

ol.li: AP-233, Structure module set draft 4, 2005-04-13
AP-233, Concept model draft 12, 2004-03-25
Sheard, Sarah, "Twelve Systems Engineering Roles". In Proceedings of the INCOSE. INCOSE, 1996

ul.li: Tom Thurman and Erik early first read exchange

ol.li: Tom says: I reviewed your proposal and am requesting more information: How does a conceptual_part differ from a system?

Erik asys: Good question Tom, Do I need both a system entity and a conceptual product entity? I do ask the same question at regular intervals, have intense debates with myself and tend to come up with justifications each time. I will put together a justification document.
Tom says: As you are putting together the justification document, the central thing (from my perspective) is to capture what explicit mechanisms are used for identification.

ul.li: Rationale

ol.li: A module set has been published within AP-233 for support of system physical architecture [Ref. 1]. These modules extend existing STEP modules based on the STEP Part concept (STEP module 1022). This design decision suggests that the AP-233 development team suggest that the physical architecture structures handled in the systems engineering process equates the product structure of the realised physical product. This impression is further underlined by statements in the concept model used for AP-233 development [Ref. 2].

Note, the selection of the STEP Part concept is significant to the author as a Part is representing "a discrete object that may come into existence as a consequence of a manufacturing process". The implication is that the part holds information for manufacturing purposes.
This document outlines an alternate approach for realising the system physical architecture modules and compares it with the one taken.

ul.li: Interpretation of structure module draft

ol.li: Representing structure using the part structure suggests that AP-233 development team has the following approach in mind.
ol.Caption: Figure 1 Simple AP-233 instantiation
ol.li: Figure 1 shows a single requirement object being allocated to a single part object within a system. The allocation is assumed to be made within the systems engineering process.
ol.Caption: Figure 2 Simple instantiation with domain engineering view added
ol.li: Figure 2 is an extension of Figure 1 showing an additional part_view_definition object added to capture a specific realisation/manufacturing view. I.e., systems ngineering and component/domain engineering share a common part/part list view on the system under development.,

This is of course only an interpretation of what the development team has in mind, but it is further underlined by the statements below taken from the concept model [2]. Part The Part is simply a part or component list. The name used follows the STEP manufacturing point of view of looking at a part or component and talking about it as an assembly because their job is to assemble it. This is a place where it may be advisable for clarity to use the words component or part as an alias for Part.

ul.li: Views on the systems engineering process

ol.li: Multiple notations are in use for capturing the systems engineering process. The V process model is in common use, Figure 3
ol.Caption: Figure 3, The V-model
ol.li: If a component in a system is complex in itself, then the process need to be applied from the top left for the component as well. I.e., the "system requirements" identified for a complex component becomes the "stakeholder requirements" for the development of the component. This part of the process may also be illustrated as in Figure 4.
ol.Caption: Figure 4, System design
ol.li: The illustration in Figure 4 is significant as it illustrates that the output specification from an activity can be seen as the input requirements for the next activity in the process (Figure 5).
ol.Caption: Figure 5 Relationship between system and component development
ol.li: In traditional document based systems engineering specifications are typically captured in a set of three documents: a - SSS for identified system requirements and definition of functional architectures. b - SSDD for capturing identified system components and allocation. I.e., the system physical structure. c - A verification document identifying the criteria the realised system shall fulfil under specified conditions for acceptance

The significance of this, and it also applies to Model Based Systems Engineering, is that the structures defined by systems engineers need not coincide with the product structures defined by the engineers closer to the realisation of the components.

ul.p: In a recent project the task was to "realise a mobile facility for evaluation of army tactical training". After reviewing the requirements and surveying the market a solution, a 3 in 1 container was selected and described at a high level of abstraction. Of course detailed requirements driving the equipment installation in the container was also identified

The important point here is of course not the solution, but that in our specifications and structures we only saw the conceptual 3-in 1 container and conceptual equipment to be installed. It did not have any measures, no unique identification, no geometry etc. The manufacturing design of the container and its components, based on the specifications did of course have all this, but it was not an issue on system level. Also important, the manufacturing view selected was only one of many potential designs for meeting the requirements.
Verification of the delivered container was performed against the criteria identified at the abstract system level
Likewise, the verification of container and the installed equipment was performed at the level of detail specified in our abstract requirements.
Moreover, we could have had multiple manufacturing design alternatives based on conceptual design of the container.

ul.li: Alternate structure module outline

ol.li: The discussion and example in the previous section suggest that there exist a difference between the system structure as defined in from a conceptual perspective and the structure as specified from a manufacturing/realisation perspective.
Figure 6 duplicates the information model from Figure 1 with the exception that a SE unique Part is used to represent the conceptual components identified in systems engineering.
ol.Caption: Figure 6 SE structure with SE part entities
ol.li: The distinction between the approaches is more apparent when realisation/manufacturing views as introduced as in Figure 7. Using this approach the realisation/manufacturing views are part of their own structure as opposed to being part of a common structure as in Figure 2.

ul.Caption: Figure 7 SE structure with link to manufacturing/realisation information

ul.li: Comparison between the two approaches
The two approaches can be compared from multiple perspectives. Here three perspectives are considered:

ol.li: Support for multiple realisation alternatives. The systems engineering view is a requirements view for realisation and hence there may be multiple design solutions meeting the requirements.

Configuration management process compliance. In the CM process multiple baselines are maintained over the life of a system. Maintenance of these baselines should be supported in the AP-233 information model.
Direct support for integration with manufacturing design. AP-233 should support the transition from conceptual design elements to realisation/manufacturing elements.

ul.li: Conclusion

ol.li: It appears that the solutions proposed in draft 4 of the system structure modules are missing modelling concepts for capturing system conceptual design. The missing functionality has several implications to the execution the development process.

It is proposed that the AP-233 structure modelling team introduces an intermediate conceptual design view separated from the standard STEP Part view. This is not to say that the Part view is inappropriate for systems engineers, just that a complimentary view is required to support system design.

A Analytical_model is a type of .

An Analytical_model_application is a type of Representation. An Analytical_model_application is the association of specific data to an
in order to unambiguously characterize some behaviour of a real or imaginary object. The behaviour exhibited by the model in a specific environment or for a range of environments for a specific experiment is an analog of behaviour exhibited by the real or imaginary object when subjected to operational conditions.
Specific expectations for the correlation of the behaviour exhibited by the model and the behaviour of the object modeled may be identified by assigning requirements to the model.

ext_description.p:
specifies the role of the
for the . The model_parameter_assignment binds instance data to data slots in the . There shall be one or more for the .
ext_description.note: For each parameter declared in a model definition, an actual value must be assigned when that model is referenced, unless there is a default assignment included in the source code for the model.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the as the basis model for the .
specifies the string for the human-interpretable identifier for this .
The analytical_model_application_name shall be unique within a population of .

An Analytical_model_definition is a type of .
An Analytical_model_definition is a mathematical description of the properties of a system.
In this part of ISO 10303 an Analytical_model_definition includes the variable declarations of the mathematical description but may not include the assignment of actual values for the variables declared. Assignment of actual values is accomplished in
This part of ISO 10303 provides support for computer systems to verify type consistency between product data defined in this part of ISO 10303 and product data captured by Analytical_model_definitions.
This part of ISO 10303 describes the interfaces (ports) to an Analytical_model_definition and provides support for type checking of the units used for the parameters that may be assigned values for an Analytical_model_definition.
Figure 1 is an example of the case where actual values are not included: the Analytical_model_definition for a resistor that is coded in pseudocode.
Analytical_model_definition of a resistor
When the Analytical_model_definition is referenced by an , literals will be supplied for parameters declared in the interface and the simulator must ensure that types are compatible.
Usually the system is exercised in experiments to evaluate the usefulness of the system in the intended application.
The language syntax and semantics of an Analytical_model_definition are not specified by this part of ISO 10303.
This part of ISO 10303 provides complete support for exchange of units, including SI units, derived units, and user declared units.
This part of ISO 10303 provides complete support for prefixes of units.

ext_description.p:
the of which the
provides a characterization

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the role of the Specification_definition ## HARMONIZE for an . The source_code contains the source code for the . Figure 1 illustrates how a source_code is specified and coded.

An Analytical_model_make_from_relationship is a type of . An Analytical_model_make_from_relationship establishes a relationship between an analytical model selected for reuse and the new analytical model that results from the reuse.
specifies an to be used for the Analytical_model_make_from_relationship.
specifies an that is the result of the reuse for the Analytical_model_make_from_relationship.

An Analytical_model_parameter is a type of . An Analytical_model_parameter is a formally declared variable of the
provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment.
In Spice, temperature is a Analytical_model_parameter that may be set at the execution time.
specifies the analytical model for which the parameter is being established.
The combination of reusable_model and resultant_model shall be unique within a population of Analytical_model_make_from_relationship.
An Analytical_model_version is a type of .

specifies a role of the
for the Analytical_model_version.

A Characteristic_data_table is a type of
that is described by one or more s. The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
specifies the list of one or more s defining the Characteristic_data_table.
A Characteristic_representation is a type of .
An Expanded_uncertainty is a type of . The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
specifies the real number for the Expanded_uncertainty.
A Maximum_tolerance_characteristic is a type of . The Maximum_tolerance_characteristic indicates the maximum allowed value for the parameter specified.

specifies the role of the for the Maximum_tolerance_characteristic. There is exactly one
for each items. The items specifies the maximum value of the
for the Maximum_tolerance_characteristic.

A Measure_qualification is a mean to provide information about measurements in which there is an associated uncertainty. The uncertainty may be specified as precision, qualitative uncertainty, or expanded uncertainty, and the type of the related datum shall be included. The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
the words by which the Measure_qualification is known.
the text that provides further information about the Measure_qualification.
specifies the for the Measure_qualification.
specifies the for the Measure_qualification. There shall be one or more
A Minimum_tolerance_characteristic is a type of . The Minimum_tolerance_characteristic indicates the minimum allowed value for the parameter specified.

specifies the nominal, minimum, and maximum values of the for the Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic. There shall be one nominal, one minimum and one maximum value for the Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic.
A Nominal_tolerance_characteristic is a type of .

A Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic is a type of . The Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic includes a minimum, maximum, and nominal characteristic numeric parameter. All three have the same base unit, but may have different prefixes.

specifies the nominal, minimum, and maximum values of the
for the Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic. There shall be one nominal, one minimum and one maximum value for the Plus_minus_tolerance_characteristic.

ext_description.p: A Precision_qualifier is a specification of the number of significant digits in the representation of a value. Precision_qualifier shall be interpreted in accordance with Precision_qualifier in part 45 of this standard.
ext_description.note: The precision is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".

ext_description.p: specifies the number of significant digits of the value.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A Qualitative_uncertainty is a type of . The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
specifies a string for the Qualitative_uncertainty.

A Range_characteristic is a type of
that specifies a range of values. The range may be open or closed. The range may be single ended.

specifies the value of the
for the Range_characteristic. There shall be exactly two
for the Range_characteristic.

specifies the classification of the Range_characteristic. The Range_characteristic shall be open , closed, lower_open or upper_open. Open shall be interpreted as not including the end point or points in the range. Closed shall be interpreted as including the end point or points in the range.

type of the first element in the
shall be the same as the type of the second element in the .

type of the of the first element in the
shall be the same as the type of the
of the second element in the .

type of the of the first element in the
shall be the same as the type of the
of the second element in the .

ext_description.p: A Standard_uncertainty is a type of . A Standard_uncertainty may be an . The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies a real value of the uncertainty.
A Statistical_tolerance_characteristic is a type of . The Statistical_tolerance_characteristic supports the exchange of properties defined by statistical distributions.

ext_description.p: A Symmetrical_tolerance_characteristic is a type of that has symmetrical tolerances around the nominal value. The structure is a nominal value with a ratio. The ratio is applied to the nominal value and applies to both plus and minus.
ext_description.example: A resistance of 22 Ohm plus or minus 10% would be represented with two values, 22 Ohm and .10 since the same quantity 10% is referenced on both sides of the nominal value.
ext_description.note: An unsymmetrical distribution would be represented with a member of .

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
specifies the value of the
for the Symmetrical_tolerance_characteristic. There shall be exactly two
for the Symmetrical_tolerance_characteristic.
A Text_representation_item is a type of .
the words by which the Text_representation_item is known.
A Tolerance_characteristic is a type of . A Tolerance_characteristic may be one of , , , , or .

ext_description.p:
specifies the role of the for the Tolerance_characteristic. There shall be one or more
for the Tolerance_characteristic.
ext_description.note: Members of this application object are not exchanged to support geometric tolerancing.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A Type_qualifier is a mean to specify an uncertainty. The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
the words by which the Type_qualifier is known.
An Uncertainty_qualifier is of one of type or . The uncertainty is defined in clause 2 of "The Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement".
specifies the string that serves to identify the Uncertainty_qualifier.
the text that provides further information about the Uncertainty_qualifier.

A Category_model_parameter is a type of . A Category_model_parameter is a formally declared variable of the
provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment. The primary use for a Category_model_parameter is for creation and sharing of catalog data element definitions.

ext_description.p:
A Model_parameter is a type of . A Model_parameter may be a or a , or additionally may be an , a , a , or a . A Model_parameter is a formally declared variable of the
provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment. The unit_of_measure for the Model_parameter shall be consistent with the unit_of_measure for the values assigned to the parameter, either as defaults or through explicit assignment. The default values are explicitly intended to be overridden by explicit assignment, when that explicit assignment references a Model_parameter.
ext_description.example: In Spice, temperature is a Model_parameter that may be set at the execution time.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the string used as the descriptive label for the unit of measure associated with the Model_parameter. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The representation of units described in ISO 10303-41 shall be used. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

specifies the of the Model_parameter. The value of this attribute need not be specified. There shall be one or more
for a Model_parameter. The valid_ranges need not be contiguous. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p:
A Parameter_assignment is a type of . A Parameter_assignment is the association of either a
or with a , used to provide actual values for characteristics declared formally by the the . The values assigned by the Parameter_assignment shall override any default values specified by the referenced by the attribute. The Parameter_assignment declares to the receiving system that the types that are associated are compatible. It is the responsibility of the sending system to ensure this is the case. Type compatibility is in the end a matter of resolving data dictionaries. This standard provides facilities for ensuring a common data dictionary is available for base types such as length, frequency.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
specifies a role of the
for the Parameter_assignment.

A Parameter_assignment_override is the association between a and another
which replaces or overrides the first . Parameter_assignment_override is used when an
is referenced but some of the . Parameter_assignments need to be replaced.
specifies the role of the for the Parameter_assignment_override.

ext_description.p:
specifies the role of the for the Parameter_assignment_override. The
binds instance data to data slots in the .
ext_description.note: For each parameter declared in a model definition, an actual value must be assigned when that model is referenced, unless there is a default assignment included in the source code for the model.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the role of the for the Parameter_assignment_override.

ext_description.p: A Schema_based_model_parameter is a type of . A Schema_based_model_parameter is a reference to an attribute and entity in a formal model for the purposes of later extracting data from a model instance or populating data in a model instance. The schema identifier uses application of the ASN 1 notation standardized in part 1 of this standard.
ext_description.example: In rule definition, it is often necessary to reference entity data types or their attributes as a parameter.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the string used as the unambiguous identifier for the entity name for the Schema_based_model_parameter.
specifies the string used as the unambiguous identifier for the attribute name for the Schema_based_model_parameter. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: specifies the string used as the unambiguous identifier for the schema for the Schema_based_model_parameter.
ext_description.example: The identifier for the AIM schema from ISO 10303-210:2001 is "{ 1 0 10303 210 1 1 1 }".

ext_descriptions.ext_description: The combination of the schema_identifier, entity_name, and attribute_name shall be unique within a population of Schema_based_model_parameter.
A Product_specific_parameter_value_assignment is the assignment of a value to a parameter in the context of a specific .
specifies a role of the for the Product_specific_parameter_value_assignment.
specifies a role of the for the Product_specific_parameter_value_assignment.
specifies the of assigned_parameter.
the of_product and the_model_parameter shall be unique within a population of the Product_specific_parameter_value_assignment.
A Software is a type of .
A Software_definition is a type of .

specifies a role of the
for the Software_definition.
A Software_version is a type of .
specifies a role of the for the Software_version.
A Rule_action is one of a , a , a , a , a , a , a , a , or a . A Rule_action is an assertion that some action has occurred toward management of rules.
specifies the as the version of a for which some management Rule_action has occurred.
A Rule_adoption is a type of that states a version of a has been adopted.
A Rule_boolean_function is a type of . A Rule_boolean_function returns a Boolean property.
A Rule_change_request is a type of that states a request has been made for modification to a version of a . The change reason shall be provided as a part of the Rule_change_request.
specifies the human-interpretable reason for requesting a Rule_change_request.
A Rule_complex_clause is consisting of one or more simple clauses that are ANDed together. The AND operator is provided by the SET aggregation in this application object.
specifies the name for the Rule_complex_clause.
The identifier shall be unique within a population of Rule_complex_clause.
A Rule_conclusion_definition is providing the conclusion part of a rule construct.
specifies the name for the Rule_conclusion_definition.
specifies the for the Rule_conclusion_definition. The rule_definition is the rule being composed by this Rule_conclusion_definition.
specifies specifies the for the Rule_conclusion_definition. There shall be one or more conjunctive_content specified for a Rule_conclusion_definition.
The combination of the rule_definition and the identifier shall be unique within a population of Rule_conclusion_definition.
A Rule_creation is a type of that states that a version of a has been created.

A Rule_definition is a type of . A Rule_definition is a formal specification that defines a constraint by relating two elements based upon characteristics of a design, one as premise and one as conclusion. The Rule_definition is for one version of a rule only.

specifies the role of the
for the Rule_definition.

specifies the role of the
for the Rule_definition.
A Rule_expiration is a type of that states that a version of a has expired.
specifies the human-interpretable reason for the Rule_expiration.

ext_description.p: A Rule_function is a formal specification for a process that includes the source code and instance values for the process. A Rule_function has a unique combination of identifier and reference_document. A Rule_function shall have at least one parameter.
ext_description.note: Source code is the computer-interpretable expressions that form a part of the Rule_function. The attribute source_code is the relationship of these expressions to the Rule_function.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the name for the Rule_function.

A Rule_function_domain_parameter is a type of . A Rule_function_domain_parameter is a formally declared variable of the
provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment. The base type of the variable is defined by the base type of the or
data. The Rule_function_domain_parameter specifies a parameter that is in the domain or input of the function.
the accessed_rule_function
The combination of the and the accessed_rule_function shall be unique within a population of Rule_function_domain_parameter.

A Rule_function_range_parameter is a type of . A Rule_function_range_parameter is a formally declared variable of the
provided for an external application to populate at execution time in a computing environment. The base type of the variable is defined by the base type of the or data. The Rule_function_range_parameter specifies a parameter that is the output of the function.
the accessed_rule_function
The combination of the and the accessed_rule_function shall be unique within a population of Rule_function_range_parameter.
A Rule_general_clause is a

ext_description.p: A Rule_general_clause is assigning data specific to the rule definition to the generic algorithm specified by rule_function. A Rule_general_clause is an application of a rule_function.
ext_description.example: An example of this type of data would be "return each track whose width attribute is less than 5 mils."

ext_description.p: specifies the or the for a Rule_general_clause. There shall be one or more parameter specified for a Rule_general_clause.
ext_description.note: This provides the recursive capability required.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A Rule_justification is a type of .
specifies the that results from the Rule_justification.
specifies the text that describes the Rule_justification.

ext_description.p: justified_action shall not be this Rule_justification.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A Rule_modification is a type of that states a version of a is a result of a request to change an existing version of an .
specifies the role of the for the Rule_modification.

A Rule_premise_definition is the premise for a rule construct. The Rule_premise_definition uses an 'OR' construct so that if any of the parts of the premise are true, the rule will fire. Each part may be a simple or complex clause.
specifies the name for the Rule_premise_definition.
specifies the for the Rule_premise_definition. The rule_definition is the rule_definition this Rule_premise_definition is helping to compose.
specifies a or a . There shall be one or more or specified for a Rule_premise_definition.
The combination of rule_definition and identifier shall be unique within a population of Rule_premise_definition.

A Rule_priority is a statement that an
that is in the rule category has a priority value. This value is used to order rules. The priority is applied to the rule through the . It is not the that has the priority.
specifies the integer for the priority number of the Rule_priority. The lowest numeric value shall have the highest priority.
specifies the integer for the priority number of the Rule_priority. The lowest numeric value shall have the highest priority.
A number less than zero shall not be allowed.
A Rule_product is a type of .
A Rule_rejection is a type of that states a version of a has been rejected. The rejection rationale shall be part of the Rule_rejection.
specifies the human-interpretable explanation for the Rule_rejection.
A Rule_request is a type of that states a version of a has been requested. The rationale for the version shall be part of the Rule_request.

ext_description.p: A Rule_set is a type of . A Rule_set is an association among .
ext_description.note:
The purpose for a Rule_set is renamed from the
attribute inherited from .

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the role of the for the Rule_set. There shall be one or more for the Rule_set.
A Rule_set_group is a type of . A Rule_set_group shall have at least two Rule_sets.
specifies the for the Rule_set_group. There may be more than two for the Rule_set_group.

ext_description.p: A Rule_simple_clause is assigning data specific to the rule definition to the generic algorithm specified by . A Rule_simple_clause is an application of a . A Rule_simple_clause is a Boolean property.
ext_description.example: An example of this type of data would be "For each track in the design, the width attribute is less than 5 mils."

ext_descriptions.ext_description: specifies the of the Rule_simple_clause. The rule_function is the rule to which the Rule_simple_clause is assigning parameters.
specifies the r the for a Rule_simple_clause. There shall be one or more parameter specified for a Rule_simple_clause.
A Rule_software_definition is a type of that encodes instructions for a rule.
specifies the role of the for the Rule_software_definition.
A Rule_submission is a type of stating that a version of a has been submitted.
specifies the text that describes the rationale for the Rule_submission.

A Rule_supersedence is a type of
stating that one has been superseded by another
specifies the that has been superseded for the Rule_supersedence.

A Rule_version is a type of . A Rule_version is the management of the assignment of to . A
may evolve with usage for any number of reasons.
specifies a role of the for the Rule_version.

an inverse relationship that specifies that the existence of the Rule_version is dependent on the existence of the that specifies the Rule_version as its . There shall be one or more for a Rule_version.
an inverse relationship that specifies that the existence of the Rule_version is dependent on the existence of the .

The rule rule_version_constraint constrains the use of
as to only.

There shall not be any instance of that refers as
and is not an instance of .

The rule rule_software_definition_constraint constrains the use of
as to only.

There shall not be any instance of that refers as
and is not an instance of .
